comments.text:
In RasterImage.cpp, the following lines are suspected to no longer be accurate per bug 666446 comment 90:

> if (!(timeout > 0)) {
>   mAnimationFinished = PR_TRUE;
>   EvaluateAnimation();
> }

Some additional information: 

bug 666446 comment 95 (:JOEDREW!):
> > Do you know if there was a reason for the existing behavior? (making 0-timeout > trigger "animation finished" behavior)
> 
> No, I am not sure why this is. Someone else might 
> be able to enlighten us further, but I think that in 
> RasterImage::StartAnimation() we only check to
> see if it's > 0, so perhaps this is what we should do here as well.

This code was introduced as "timeout >= 0" in CVS revision 1.5 of the file:

http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsview2.cgi?diff_mode=context&whitespace_mode=show&root=/cvsroot&subdir=mozilla/modules/libpr0n/src&command=DIFF_FRAMESET&file=imgContainer.cpp&rev2=1.5&rev1=1.4

and then modified in revision 1.8 to be "> 0":

http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsview2.cgi?diff_mode=context&whitespace_mode=show&root=/cvsroot&subdir=mozilla/modules/libpr0n/src&command=DIFF_FRAMESET&file=imgContainer.cpp&rev2=1.8&rev1=1.7

Unfortunately neither of these revisions were linked to bugs, and my bugzilla searching has not come up with anything, which makes me think it was a sort of over-the-shoulder development that was common in the project at the time.

bug 666446 comment 96, (:jesup):
I can add some historical context.

Animated GIFs were animating too fast in some cases, and IE (and maybe NS4) had put a minimum on the timeouts for animgifs.  That was the purpose of the 1.8 checkin. 

I *suspect* the reason for changing how 0 is handled was to a) avoid it sucking 100% of the CPU if there wasn't a a lower limit and it repeats, and b) if an anim is a run-once anim, the effect of a 0 timeout was to jump to the end.  But that's fuzzy.

I have a fuzzy memory of the discussions around this change; I was involved.  Not sure if they were in newsgroups or a bug.  Look for bugs closed by pav or hyatt in that timeframe.

bug 666446 comment 97 (:jesup):
See bug 125137 for a related issue; it notes that IE of the era had a minimum anim timeout of 100ms.

After much searching I haven't found a bug associated with hyatt's checkin; perhaps searching on the sr= in the text will find it.

Review of attachment 689685:
-----------------------------------------------------------------

We're going to need a test for this, if we can do it. Let's start with a non-automated test, just to verify functionality, and then move to an automated one (if we can). Here's what I'd recommend you do:

Create two animated images (.gif is fine). Each of these should have 2 frames - let's make them 100x100px squares. The first frame will have a red square, and the second frame will have a blue square. Both of them should specify timeout=0 (meaning there is a 0-ms time between frame 1 and frame 2). The first image should loop indefinitely, and the second one should not.

Once we have these images, we'll put them into a webpage, build the code with the patch you've specified, and then run it on this test. For the non-automated versions, you're looking for two things: 1) that the looping image doesn't use 100% of the CPU (or some strange, very high amount, either), and 2) that the non-looping image stays on the last frame (the blue frame) indefinitely. 

I usually use The Gimp to create images like this - www.gimp.org.

Also, you'll need to specify your hg username and a commit comment when the patch is ready. Commit messages should be in the form:

Bug XXXXXX: <description of what you changed and why> r=<reviewer>

You can change this by pushing your patch and then running: 
hg qref -m "<commit message>

This will save it to your patch, so you don't need to do it every time. You can specify your username by entering the following into your ~/.hgrc file:

[ui]
username = John Doe <john@example.com>

Where in place of 'John Doe', you'd have your name, and in place of 'john@example.com', you'd have your email address. You only need to do this once for all your mercurial patches, so once it's done, you should be good (unless you somehow delete your .hgrc file).

::: image/src/RasterImage.cpp
@@ +558,5 @@
>      // Wait until the next refresh driver tick and try again
>      return false;
>    }
>  
> +  if (timeout == 0) {

I think this change looks good, but let's double check with Joe.
